_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Executive Summary briefly reviews the major elements of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for Dakota Spirit AgEnergy, LLC's (DSA) dry mill ethanol production facility located near Spiritwood, ND. This summary is presented in response to the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 (40 CFR 68) and Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act. The DSA ethanol facility is subject to the RMP rule due to the storage of natural gasoline (denaturant), a regulated flammable mixture, above the respective threshold quantity.  This RMP submittal is to meet the five (5) year submission requirements of the EPA Title 40 Part 68 requirements for the facility.



1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

 

DSA is committed to protecting the environment and operating facilities in a manner that promotes the safety of employees and the general public. Management has adopted and implemented policies that adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations. The design and construction of the facility has incorporated physical and operational safeguards to prevent accidental releases. Through the proper design, installation, operation and maintenance of the equipment, and the training of our personnel, DSA has minimized the hazard to human health and the environment from fires, explosions, or any unplanned sudden or non-sudden release of hazardous materials.  



In the event that a release does occur, the facility's emergency response actions are described in its facility response plan. The facility response plan includes procedures to coordinate response actions with local emergency response personnel (i.e., law enforcement, fire, and rescue departments, emergency medical services, hospital and government personnel, etc.) as well as any potentially affected neighbors.  In addition, the facility response plan is used to familiarize local emergency response personne

l with the types of materials handled and internal emergency response procedures.



2.    Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled



The DSA facility is an 80 million gallon per year corn-based dry-mill denatured ethanol fuel production facility. Ethanol is produced through the conversion of corn starch to sugars and then conversion of the sugars to ethanol (i.e., grain alcohol) through a continuous fermentation and distillation process. 



Regulated substances stored at the facility include natural gasoline, which is used as a denaturant in the ethanol fuel product.



3.    Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



DSA has programs in place to address accidental release prevention measures required by EPA, Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), and notification requirements of EPA's Emergency Response and Community Right-to-Know regulations. The facility complies with PSM for the management of ethanol and natural gasoline (denaturant).



Employee Participation



DSA has developed an employee participation program. All process safety information, process hazard analysis (PHA) results, recommendations, action items, incident investigations, compliance audits, operating procedures, emergency response plan, and records of management of change are available to the operating personnel at any time.



Process Hazard Analysis and Process Safety Information



The facility utilizes the hazard and operability study (HAZOP) PHA methodology. The PHA identified the following potential major hazards: fire, explosion, over-pressurization, corrosion, over-filling and equipment failure. The facility utilizes process controls such as vents, relief valves, check valves, manual shutoffs, automatic shutoffs, interlocks, alarms and procedures, and grounding equipment to prevent or limit releases.  



DSA keeps a variety of technical documentation that is used to help

maintain safe operation of the facility. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDSs). The facility also maintains technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, pressure relief design and calculations, and piping and instrumentation drawings.



Operating Procedures and Training



DSA maintains written procedures that address all modes of process operations, including normal operations, manual operation, and emergency shutdown. The facility has developed and implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in facility operations.  



Contractors



The contractor safety procedures establish minimum guidelines and activities in order to assure that the contractor's employees follow safe work practices and procedures. The procedures include a contractor screening process and hazard awareness, safety and emergency procedures training. All contractors performing work on or near a covered process is required to undergo Contractor Prequalification prior to acceptance as a qualified contractor to perform work at the facility.



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews



DSA performs a Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.



Mechanical Integrity



The facility's mechanical integrity program includes written procedures, training, and regular inspections and equipment testing procedures to maintain bulk storage tanks, piping systems, relief systems, and pumps in a safe operating condition.  



M

anagement of Change



The facility's Management of Change (MOC) program reviews all proposed changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, materials, and design conditions prior to implementation of the change. Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by a process change.  



Incident Investigation



DSA has procedures to promptly investigate any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a release of an RMP regulated substance. The procedure establishes the minimum guidelines and activities of the incident investigation program in order to reduce the likelihood of repetitive occurrences of events which could reasonably lead to catastrophic releases. Investigations will be undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent a similar release in the future.



Compliance Audits



The facility will perform regular compliance audits of the provisions of RMP to verify that procedures and practices developed under the standard are adequate and are being followed. The audit will include a review of documentation and process safety information, inspection of the physical facilities, and interviews with all levels of plant personnel.



4.      Accident History



The facility has not had any accidents reportable under RMP since start-up of facility operations. 



5.    Emergency Response Program



DSA maintains written emergency response procedures within the facility response plan. The intent of the facility response plan is to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The facility response plan addresses aspects of emergency response, including proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation procedures and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occu

rs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, DSA has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. DSA works with the local fire department and emergency responders to ensure the proper execution of our plan. The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes, management practices, and/or procedures.



6.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The DSA facility has been designed and constructed to meet existing construction and process safety requirements. DSA will continue to evaluate and implement changes as necessary to improve safety at the facility. At the time of this RMP submission, all prior PHA findings have been implemented with no immediate changes planned to improve safety.
